title: Sebastian Maniscalco
text:
Sebastian Maniscalco (; ; born July 8, 1973) is an American stand-up comedian and actor. Born in <a href="Arlington%20Heights%2C%20Illinois">Arlington Heights, Illinois</a>, a suburb of Chicago, Maniscalco began his career in 1998 performing at <a href="open%20mic">open mic</a>s. He has since released five comedy specials. Maniscalco has also had supporting acting roles in the films "<a href="Green%20Book%20%28film%29">Green Book</a>" (2018) and "<a href="The%20Irishman">The Irishman</a>" (2019), playing mobster <a href="Joe%20Gallo">Joe Gallo</a> in the latter.
Early life.
Maniscalco was born on July 8, 1973, in the <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a> suburb of <a href="Arlington%20Heights%2C%20Illinois">Arlington Heights, Illinois</a>, to Italian immigrants; his father Salvatore Maniscalco, who worked as a hairstylist, immigrated to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> with his family from <a href="Cefal%C3%B9">Cefalù</a>, <a href="Sicily">Sicily</a>, at the age of 15. His mother Rose Maniscalco was a secretary, and her family has origins in <a href="Naples">Naples</a>, <a href="Campania">Campania</a> and Sicily. Maniscalco is a <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a>, and at eight years old, he was an <a href="altar%20boy">altar boy</a> at St. Cecilia Catholic Church in suburban <a href="Mount%20Prospect%2C%20Illinois">Mount Prospect, Illinois</a>. He is an alum of <a href="Rolling%20Meadows%20High%20School">Rolling Meadows High School</a>. He graduated from <a href="Northern%20Illinois%20University">Northern Illinois University</a> in 1995, where he was the president of the <a href="Sigma%20Pi">Sigma Pi</a> fraternity chapter, with a degree in communication studies. After moving to <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a> in 1998, Maniscalco performed at open mics in bars and bowling alleys while working as a waiter at the Four Seasons Hotel in <a href="Beverly%20Hills%2C%20California">Beverly Hills, California</a>, where he worked from 1998 to 2005.
Career.
In 2005, he began performing regularly at <a href="The%20Comedy%20Store">The Comedy Store</a> in <a href="West%20Hollywood%2C%20California">West Hollywood, California</a>. Maniscalco cites <a href="Jerry%20Seinfeld">Jerry Seinfeld</a>, <a href="George%20Carlin">George Carlin</a>, <a href="Brian%20Regan%20%28comedian%29">Brian Regan</a>, <a href="John%20Ritter">John Ritter</a>, <a href="Johnny%20Carson">Johnny Carson</a>, <a href="Andrew%20Dice%20Clay">Andrew Dice Clay</a>, <a href="Bill%20Burr">Bill Burr</a>, and <a href="Don%20Rickles">Don Rickles</a> as comedic influences. Since then, he has done a half-hour for <a href="Comedy%20Central%20Presents">Comedy Central Presents</a> and five hour-long specials. His first special, "Sebastian Live", was released on June 2, 2009. His next three specials were aired on Showtime, with "What's Wrong with People?" released on January 5, 2012, "Aren't You Embarrassed?", taped in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, released on November 14, 2014, and "Why Would You Do That?", taped in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> and released in 2016.
Maniscalco was one of four comedians featured in <a href="Vince%20Vaughn">Vince Vaughn</a>'s ', along with <a href="Ahmed%20Ahmed">Ahmed Ahmed</a>, <a href="John%20Caparulo">John Caparulo</a>, and <a href="Bret%20Ernst">Bret Ernst</a>. Maniscalco has been on <a href="Russell%20Peters">Russell Peters</a>' "Best Night Ever", "Comedy Central Presents", "<a href="The%20Late%20Late%20Show%20with%20Craig%20Ferguson">The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson</a>", "<a href="The%20Tonight%20Show%20with%20Jay%20Leno">The Tonight Show with Jay Leno</a>", "<a href="The%20Jay%20Leno%20Show">The Jay Leno Show</a>", "<a href="The%20Tonight%20Show%20Starring%20Jimmy%20Fallon">The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon</a>", "<a href="Conan%20%28talk%20show%29">Conan</a>", and "<a href="The%20Late%20Show%20with%20Stephen%20Colbert">The Late Show with Stephen Colbert</a>". Additionally, he appeared in several films, such as ', "<a href="The%20House%20%282017%20film%29">The House</a>", "<a href="Tag%20%282018%20film%29">Tag</a>", and "<a href="Cruise%20%28film%29">Cruise</a>", and he co-hosts a podcast titled "The Pete and Sebastian Show" with fellow comedian <a href="Pete%20Correale">Pete Correale</a>. As of January 2017, they have a show on Sirius XM satellite radio's <a href="Raw%20Dog%20Comedy">Raw Dog Comedy</a> channel 99. In 2016, Maniscalco appeared on the seventh season of "<a href="Comedians%20in%20Cars%20Getting%20Coffee">Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee</a>". He published his memoir "Stay Hungry" on February 27, 2018. A Netflix special also titled "Stay Hungry" was released on January 15, 2019.
In 2018, Maniscalco made his feature film debut, as Johnny Venere in the Academy Award-winning film "<a href="Green%20Book%20%28film%29">Green Book.</a>" Maniscalco hosted the <a href="2019%20MTV%20Video%20Music%20Awards">2019 MTV Video Music Awards</a> on August 26. In November 2019, Maniscalco appeared in <a href="Martin%20Scorsese">Martin Scorsese</a>'s "<a href="The%20Irishman">The Irishman</a>" playing <a href="Joe%20Gallo">"Crazy" Joe Gallo</a> alongside <a href="Robert%20De%20Niro">Robert De Niro</a>, <a href="Joe%20Pesci">Joe Pesci</a>, and <a href="Al%20Pacino">Al Pacino</a>. He also hosted the three-part companion podcast for the film, first published on December 2, 2019, titled "Behind the Irishman".
In June 2021, it was announced that Maniscalco will host a reality television show titled "Well Done With Sebastian Maniscalco" that premiered on August 12, 2021 on <a href="Discovery%2B">Discovery+</a> where he will be joined by friends and family to explore food culture and etiquette. Four days after the premiere, the show was renewed for a six-episode second season that will premiere on November 16, 2021. In August 2021, during a podcast, he announced that he was a part of the cast of <a href="Illumination%20%28animation%20company%29">Illumination</a>'s "<a href="List%20of%20non-video%20game%20media%20featuring%20Mario%23Upcoming%20animated%20film%20%282022%29">Mario</a>" film, playing the role of Spike from the game "<a href="Wrecking%20Crew%20%28video%20game%29">Wrecking Crew</a>" as <a href="Mario">Mario</a> and <a href="Luigi">Luigi</a>'s boss.
Personal life.
Maniscalco married Lana Gomez in August 2013. The couple has two children together: a daughter named Serafina (after Maniscalco's grandmother) born in May 2017, and a son named Caruso born in June 2019.
